turn.label: Mr. John G. Pidgeon
turn.text: Trial?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- motion for new trial, motion for a new trial on this new evidence?

turn.speaker: john_g_pidgeon
turn.label: Mr. John G. Pidgeon
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, why is that?

That was a proceeding that was still going on under the remedies available under your state law and therefore, I should think Mr. Morgan that he was in the case as well advised not to file the petition for certiorari here until that supplementary proceeding in your state court was -- was completed.
Am I wrong about that?

turn.speaker: john_g_pidgeon
turn.label: Mr. John G. Pidgeon
turn.text: You have -- it might be very true, but that's not my position.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And therefore -- therefore, my question to you, if the petition which this Court or if the petition which was filed on October 24th, 1955 was within the 90 days of the final disposition of everything that was open under Arizona procedure, he is quite within our rule.

turn.speaker: john_g_pidgeon
turn.label: Mr. John G. Pidgeon
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And -- and the petition for certiorari having been denied, he then was entitled to bring his petition for his application for habeas corpus and indeed, he couldn't have brought it before, could he?
He had to come here under Darr and Burford.

turn.speaker: john_g_pidgeon
turn.label: Mr. John G. Pidgeon
turn.text: Yes, he did.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And therefore, I should think it was all according to (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: john_g_pidgeon
turn.label: Mr. John G. Pidgeon
turn.text: But he --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He could consider it.

turn.speaker: john_g_pidgeon
turn.label: Mr. John G. Pidgeon
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, but all terms --

turn.speaker: john_g_pidgeon
turn.label: Mr. John G. Pidgeon
turn.text: If that is --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- that all terms whether he came here within 90 days of the last stage of Arizona procedure.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Under your procedure, an appeal is allowed from the judgment and also a separate appeal is allowed from the order on a subsequent motion for a new trial.
That was done in this case (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: john_g_pidgeon
turn.label: Mr. John G. Pidgeon
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice Whittaker.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: That's a little peculiar to me.
I've never heard of procedure like that, but let me ask this question.

Is it your position that a petition for certiorari must have been filed insofar as it -- to sought review of the judgment of guilty within the 60 days after affirmance by the Supreme Court of -- of Arizona of the judgment of guilty?

turn.speaker: john_g_pidgeon
turn.label: Mr. John G. Pidgeon
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, at 90 days.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: 90 days and that the motion for a new trial which was a separate appeal was a separate proceeding, is that what you're saying?

turn.speaker: john_g_pidgeon
turn.label: Mr. John G. Pidgeon
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
He can file a motion for a new trial on the grounds of newly discovered evidence tomorrow, if he wants to.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But, Mr. Pidgeon, if -- if Mr. Morgan had filed a petition for certiorari in this Court after the disposition of the main trial in your Supreme Court and there has been pending a motion for a new trial under Arizona law, I should think you would've said to this Court, "Those -- this is a premature petition for certiorari because non-concept, the motion for a new trial is that you might be granted in this Arizona court?”
And therefore, the questions on which you're asked this rather petition, would become nonexistent, isn't that true?

turn.speaker: john_g_pidgeon
turn.label: Mr. John G. Pidgeon
turn.text: That's possibly true, but if we follow that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Would it be possible because this Court certainly wouldn't grant a petition for certiorari in a capital case when there is before --

turn.speaker: john_g_pidgeon
turn.label: Mr. John G. Pidgeon
turn.text: If we do it, yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: There is before the -- some lower court in Arizona, a motion for a new trial in that very case and I shouldn't think we wouldn't speculate whether we knew it or not, I assume counsel's duty would be to tell the court.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Did he file (Inaudible) come to our attention that there's a motion for a new trial?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That isn't the secret among lawyers who filed motions or prosecutors against whom it is filed, is it?

turn.speaker: john_g_pidgeon
turn.label: Mr. John G. Pidgeon
turn.text: No, it's no secret, pardon me?
Well then the rule requiring that 90-day -- to file your petition for certiorari within 90 days --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Doesn't begin to run until the whole procedure which is opened by a state law is completed.

turn.speaker: john_g_pidgeon
turn.label: Mr. John G. Pidgeon
turn.text: And -- and that can be done at anytime.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What?

turn.speaker: john_g_pidgeon
turn.label: Mr. John G. Pidgeon
turn.text: That can be done at anytime, as he files his new motions for a new trial.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, that all depends on state procedure for the state allows such a motion forever.
And the case isn't closed, but there is, in fact, an exercise of that power to file a motion for new trial.
There's no case for this Court, non-concept, the State wouldn't take care of it.

turn.speaker: john_g_pidgeon
turn.label: Mr. John G. Pidgeon
turn.text: Well, the Court understands my position and --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, I -- I think -- I think we do, Mr. Pidgeon.

turn.speaker: john_g_pidgeon
turn.label: Mr. John G. Pidgeon
turn.text: -- right or wrong.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: [Laughs]

turn.speaker: john_g_pidgeon
turn.label: Mr. John G. Pidgeon
turn.text: The second matter -- the Court will bare with me for just a few moments --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_g_pidgeon
turn.label: Mr. John G. Pidgeon
turn.text: -- is the fact that the other evidence outside of this particular oral confession to the Court does show is sufficient in and of itself to show that this man was guilty of the crime of which he was charged.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Is -- that's Stroble, as I remember, that that being irrelevant, the confession was involuntary.

turn.speaker: john_g_pidgeon
turn.label: Mr. John G. Pidgeon
turn.text: Yes, if this Court says from a matter of the uncontradicted evidence that's involuntary, that is true.

But if, as in the Stein case, where it is questionable, and I certainly think that that is, at least, the case here that it is questionable whether this was involuntary or not, that if there is sufficient evidence otherwise, then the decision should stand if it's submitted in -- in the right way.
Now, as far as I'm concerned in this particular case, the confession which was admitted to the jury was voluntary and there's no question of that.

Now, Mr. Polley has argued that, but in the event that it is questionable, then I believe that the rule of the Stein case applies that it was submitted to the jury under a proper instruction and that there is sufficient evidence with which to convict and therefore, they're not entitled to their habeas corpus.
But rather than take up the Court's time, those facts do appear in the brief, the other facts.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. Pidgeon.

turn.speaker: john_g_pidgeon
turn.label: Mr. John G. Pidgeon
turn.text: Thank you for the additional time.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Thank you.
Mr. -- you have some time for rebuttal, Mr. --

turn.speaker: w_edward_morgan
turn.label: Mr. W. Edward Morgan
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice.

I like to point out to you the record and give you the notation of it in the state transcript at page 2137 about the -- the very important witness, Mr. Byrd who was unconcerned with the case and therefore, was the only person who gave accurate testimony as to what happened at the roping.
And particularly with reference to the purported statement of the Sheriff, Mr. Jack Howard, at page 2136 of the state transcript -- 2137, he continues to say -- I -- on 2136 --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Who says?

turn.speaker: w_edward_morgan
turn.label: Mr. W. Edward Morgan
turn.text: This is the witness, Mr. Byrd.
Who -- (Inaudible) Byrd who was referred to by --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's the merchant?

turn.speaker: w_edward_morgan
turn.label: Mr. W. Edward Morgan
turn.text: Yes, this is the merchant.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: w_edward_morgan
turn.label: Mr. W. Edward Morgan
turn.text: This is the independent witness and regarding the statement of the Sheriff.
And I asked him at 2136, "Did you hear Jack Howard tell the man, you murdered that woman out there, didn't you?
You heard that part of it, didn't you?"
Answer, “No, I didn't.
I, after Jack Howard, told him he was under arrest and told him to get up, I turned around and walked away and I couldn't -- I wasn't paying any attention to what was said.”

This was -- remember, if the Court please, that all of the witnesses who testified in the -- in this ancillary procedure outside the presence of the jury where officers holding their political job under the Sheriff.
No tenure, they're just employees of the Sheriff.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Morgan.

turn.speaker: w_edward_morgan
turn.label: Mr. W. Edward Morgan
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: May I ask you this --

turn.speaker: w_edward_morgan
turn.label: Mr. W. Edward Morgan
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- assuming that on -- of course, in every respect of -- of intention to be accurate to counsel in this case, would you say that one could really form a fair estimate of what took place without reading at least that part of the record?

turn.speaker: w_edward_morgan
turn.label: Mr. W. Edward Morgan
turn.text: I don't -- I don't believe so.
I think you have to read the transcript.
I can't see how you get around.
We wanted the transcript printed in full and I felt the cause --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: May I ask --

turn.speaker: w_edward_morgan
turn.label: Mr. W. Edward Morgan
turn.text: -- proceeding in forma pauperis and felt terribly bad about --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: May I -- would -- would you go -- start again and tell us what you're just telling us, about you wanted the whole transcript.

turn.speaker: w_edward_morgan
turn.label: Mr. W. Edward Morgan
turn.text: Well I -- I --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Go from there.
Tell us (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: w_edward_morgan
turn.label: Mr. W. Edward Morgan
turn.text: Well, we felt that we would need the entire transcript, but in good conscience to this Court, where the Court was paying for the transcript [Laughs] it was -- we just didn't feel that we could invite --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: w_edward_morgan
turn.label: Mr. W. Edward Morgan
turn.text: -- this court to the expense and this trial took 18 --
